awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Deep Integration of Thin Flexible Autonomous Microsystems for Vision Correction
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this work is the realization of autonomous cyber-physical, microsystems for automated correction of blurred vision using flexible electronic contact lenses. The vision correction system integrates thin variable power lenses with object distance microsensors and computation and control software to continuously produce sharply-focused images in individuals suffering from presbyopia. Presbyopia, or loss of the eye's ability to change focus, is an inevitable and universal age-related condition that affects aging adults, causing blurred images and visual impairment. In 2018, two billion people worldwide were estimated to suffer from presbyopia. The proposed vision correction microsystem operates autonomously while collecting energy from its surrounding environment in order to provide continuous vision correction for an entire day. Realization of such microsystems advances our scientific knowledge of autonomous microsystem engineering for medical applications, ultimately improving the daily lives and well-being of billions of aging adults while reducing the cost of treatment.

The implementation of autonomous microsystems for vision correction requires deep integration of ultrathin state-of-the-art inhomogeneous microtechnologies including variable power liquid-crystal lenses, paper-thin embedded microprocessors and communications circuits with tens of millions of transistors, paper-thin microsensors to detect light level, user orientation and focal distance, and thin photovoltaic cells with power management circuits, all integrated onto a single flexible package that conforms to the surface of the human eye. The system must be able to scavenge power and manage its operation completely autonomously, in the best possible way, in a resource-limited biological environment. Advancements in systems with these characteristics are widely applicable to many future cyber physical systems (CPS) for medical and health monitoring applications. This extremely ambitious project pushes the frontiers of inhomogeneous microtechnology integration to a level that has been repeatedly dreamed of, but never realized before, to produce a highly integrated CPS that can benefit billions of people.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Presbyopia is an age-related refractive disorder caused bythe loss of focal tunability of the eye crystalline lens. More than 1.8 billion people suffer from Presbyopia. Common methods to treat presbyopia are eyeglasses and contact lens. Fundamentally the restoration of normal vision in presbyopes requires not fixed but variable/ tunable focus lenses that can adjust their optical power and cancel out the presbyope refractive error at all object distances..Our research aims to create a smart contact lens that can detect distance of the object the user is focusing at and then based on user's lack of accommodation, provide the required power. Several subsystems were developed to reach this goal.

First, a flexible substrate was developed on which, all components can be mounted when flat, and then curve and join to form a dome-shaped contact lens. Second, a flexible interconnect was developed which is a stack of Aluminum and N-doped polysilicon. Higher fracture strength of the polysilicon enables higher degrees of bending. Third, two different gaze and object distance sensing methods were developd. The first involved quad scleral coils. The field generated by one set of coils is read by the second set of coils and distance is calculated based on the amount of field induced. The second method involves using a magnetometer on each eye. The magnetic field is sensed at each eye and simple trigonometry helps calculate object distance.

Next, we developed several power generation methods. Two of the developed methods involve the fabrication of flexible, semi-transparent silicon solar cells and an ey-tear activated metal air battey. These two power generation methods were combined together along with a power management IC to provide a steady 3.3 v to the system. Furthermore, a refractive-type liquid crystal tunable fresnel lens was developed. This lens had a tunable range of over 6D. Presbyopes only require up to 3 D of accommodation. This lens can be driven with a variable voltage, as well as with a variable duty cycle.

Previously, models of accommodtion were developed empirically based on patient trials.According to them an illumination dependent piecewise linear model fits well to the presbyopic patient data. A flexible PCB was developed on which all the electronic components are soldered on. The PCB is curved and then joined. The power pack was then soldered on to the pcb along with the solar cells and etmab. The lens was then fixed on to the subsrate. Patient models were stored on the onbard microcontroller. Based on the distance detected by the magnetometers, the microntroller applies aproprate pwm pulses to the tunable lens to change its optical power. Lastly, a method of encapsulation was developed where PDMS was bonded to Polyimide with the help of an intermediate SiO2 layer. The bond strength was also characterized

  • Autonomous self-focusing smart contact lens without the final skin coating. The microsystem includes a microwatt LC varifocal lens, a microwatt distance sensor, a power scavenging module, a microcontroller and a bluetooth radio link all on a flexible substrate conforming to the eye surface.
